text: New World monkeys are all simian primates. They are endemic to South and Central America. ==Taxon classification== To learn what a Taxon Classification is, see Taxonomy (biology). * Infraorder Simiiformes ** Parvorder Platyrrhini - New World monkeys *** Family Callitrichidae: marmosets and tamarins **** Genus Callithrix **** Genus Mico **** Genus Callibella **** Genus Cebuella **** Genus Leontopithecus: lion tamarins **** Genus Saguinus **** Genus Callimico *** Family Cebidae: capuchins and squirrel monkeys **** Genus Cebus: capuchins **** Genus Saimiri: squirrel monkeys *** Family Aotidae: night or owl monkeys, also called douroucoulis **** Genus Aotus *** Family Pitheciidae: titis, sakis and uakaris **** Subfamily Callicebinae ***** Genus Callicebus **** Subfamily Pitheciinae ***** Genus Pithecia ***** Genus Chiropotes ***** Genus Cacajao *** Family Atelidae: howler, spider and woolly monkeys **** Subfamily Alouattinae ***** Genus Alouatta **** Subfamily Atelinae ***** Genus Ateles ***** Genus Brachyteles ***** Genus Lagothrix ***** Genus Oreonax ==Key== Scientific name The formal name of the species (known as the Latin name) Common name The name people most often use for the species Classified Date in which the species was described and classified Average size Average size of adult members of the species, in metric and English weight units Conservation status Conservation status of the species, per IUCN as of 2008 == Extant species == === Family: Callitrichidae === Scientific name Common name Classified Average size Conservation status References Callithrix jacchus Common marmoset 1758 Linnaeus Rylands & Mittermeier pp. 23-54 Callithrix penicillata Black-tufted marmoset 1812 É.
